getOrientation

public Stone.Orientation getOrientation()

nextOrientation

public void nextOrientation()
To be called after this stone has been rotated. Sets this stone's orientation to its logical successor. The order is as follows: TOPUP - TOPRIGHT - TOPDOWN - TOPLEFT

getType

public abstract int getType()
Returns the type of this stone, encoded as one of the int constants defined in the Stone class.

Returns:
the appropriate int constant value for this stone's type

setColor

public void setColor(int color)

hitTest

public boolean hitTest(int x,
                       int y)
Tests whether a brick of this stone is allocated at the provided point.

Parameters:
x - x-coordinate within the Grid
y - y-coordinate within the Grid
Returns:
true, if there is a brick at (x, y)
See Also:
hitTest(Point)

hitTest

public boolean hitTest(Point point)
Tests whether a brick of this stone is allocated at the provided point.

Parameters:
point - Point to be tested
Returns:
true, if there is a brick at the position described by point
See Also:
hitTest(int, int)

boundingBox

public final Rect boundingBox()
The smallest rectangle completely surrounding this stone regardless of its orientation.

Returns:
The smallest surrounding Rect r such that each coordinate of the rectangle is the respective coordinate of the outermost brick in that corresponding direction.

initializeAllocation

protected abstract void initializeAllocation()

rotatable

public abstract boolean rotatable()
Whether this stone is rotatable, i. e., whether it makes sense to rotate it. Technically every stone can be rotated, but you might want to avoid this behavior for stones that don't change their appearance when rotated to improve runtime performance, as it is the case for BlockStones.

Returns:
true, if it is necessary to (really) rotate this stone when user input requests so.

setAllocationInBoundingBox

public void setAllocationInBoundingBox(boolean[][] allocation)
Sets this stone's allocation within its bounding box. The parameter allocation has therefor got to have the same dimensions as the bounding box, such that allocation[x][y] points to the xth column within the yth row of the bounding box. An element of the array which evaluates to true indicates a brick at that very position; a false element is a position without a brick.

Parameters:
allocation - A two-dimensional array of booleans indicating where inside the bounding box the bricks are located.
See Also:
getAllocationInBoundingBox(), boundingBox()

getAllocationInBoundingBox

public boolean[][] getAllocationInBoundingBox()
Get the stone's allocation within its bounding box, describing the essential structure of the stone.

Returns:
A two-dimensional array of booleans indicating where inside the bounding box the bricks are located, as described in setAllocationInBoundingBox(boolean[][]).
See Also:
setAllocationInBoundingBox(boolean[][]), boundingBox()

onStoneFixed

public void onStoneFixed(Stone stone)
Description copied from interface: StoneFixListener
Called whenever a Stone has beend fixed on the Grid

Specified by:
onStoneFixed in interface StoneFixListener
Parameters:
stone - The Stone that has been fixed.
See Also:
Grid.fixStone(Stone)
